pgTitle: List of Scheduled Monuments in Cheshire (1066–1539)

rows.text: A rectangular water-filled moat measuring about 54m x 55m with a fishpond and connecting channel.
Originally a grange, then a moated manor house. The moat, fishpond and the building platform are scheduled. Bewsey Old Hall stands on the platform.
A rectangular waterlogged moat with an overgrown platform and a causeway.
A medieval village now deserted. Aerial photography has shown small house platforms and a former road.
A former moated manor house. Most of the platform is now occupied by a more modern farmhouse and garden.
The platform of the former chapel is marked by a 20th-century memorial pillar. To the southeast are earthworks remaining from the old hall.
A steep-sided motte with no signs of a bailey, 23m in diameter and 2.8m high. An excavation found only black soil.
The pool was abandoned around 1750 and reinstated in 1977.

These consist of an almost complete circuit round the city, miles (km) long, including four gates and several towers linked by a red sandstone wall. The north and east walls follow the Roman foundations, while the south and west walls were extended in the medieval period.
The moated site and three associated fishponds are scheduled. The site contains a house in two ranges, one built about 1330 and the other in the mid-16th century.
The site is mainly covered by newer buildings but the west arm of the moat can be traced on the lawn.
The flat-topped motte is 3.3m high and the bailey is well-defined.
A moated site formerly occupied by Dodleston Hall. The moat is almost complete other than the southeast corner which is covered by buildings.
A rectangular moat with a further moated site to the southwest and four fishponds to the northwest.
An oval mound scheduled as a motte; it is partly surrounded by a ditch and banks.
A rectangular platform 50m x 30m surrounded by a dry moat with a ditch to the west and south.
An almost square moat with a causeway across the north arm and a channel at the northwest corner leading to a fishpond.
This consists of a dry moat enclosing an area 15m wide with a bank and ditch in the west and south.
The probable site of a medieval wood-burning glass furnace which was discovered in 1933. It was excavated in 1933–35 and again in 1947.
Evidence of several ditched enclosures shown by aerial photography which are overlain by an ornamental moat. These probably represent a deserted village.
A stone 1.3m in diameter and 0.4m high marking the boundary between Nether Alderley and Over Alderley.
Earthworks of a square moat and a causeway leading towards the church.
An earthwork which is scheduled as a motte and bailey.
A square moat, largely water-logged, which formerly enclosed Hatton Hall.
Aerial photography has revealed evidence of a medieval village and a field system.
This consists of the stone socket for a cross. The shaft is missing.
An almost complete waterlogged moat accessed by a stone bridge and a causeway. The platform is occupied by a 17th-century farmhouse.
A platform surrounded by a dry moat, with two small fishponds and a dam.
The moat and the ground beneath the bridge and the hall are scheduled.
A square platform surrounded by a bank.
A large moat, now dry, surrounding an area of acres (ha) on which Iddinshall Hall stood.
A curving ditched enclosure comprising one-third of a former moat. It is the only circular medieval moated site in Cheshire.
Earthworks of a former moat and fishponds.
A chapel originally dedicated to St Helena, later to St John, stood on the site and was demolished in 1741.
A moated site 52m x 43m formerly containing Lea Hall, the middle arm of which has been filled in.
It consists of a square stone with a hollowed top on a 19th-century plinth, thought to have been a wayside cross and also a plague stone. It is listed at GradeII.
A square moated platform with a dry ditch formerly occupied by Lovel's Hall.
A water-filled moat. partly lined with sandstone, with a platform now occupied by the 15th-century Lower Huxley Hall and its gardens.
A trapezoidal piece of sandstone with a chamber on the front face. Possibly the base of a wayside cross or a plague cross. It is listed at GradeII.
The cross has a medieval octagonal base of seven steps. The rest of the cross was added in 1873. It is listed at GradeII.
A moated site which contained a monastic grange which is accessed by a bridge with associated fishponds. The site includes the mutilated socket stone of a sandstone cross.
A moated site with eight fishponds and connecting channels. It was originally a monastic grange and later the site of Middleton Hall and a chapel.
A square moat about 80m across, grass-covered and normally dry.
A complete double moat, the external moat being dry and the inner one water-filled. A dry fishpond connects to the outer moat.
Square platform 10m wide surrounded by a water-filled moat.
Built in buff and red sandstone, this consists of a massive square base on which are three steps and a cube-shaped block. Into this is set a broken rectangular shaft. It is listed at GradeII.
A rectangular platform surrounded by a water-filled moat on which is a modern farmhouse.
A dry rectangular moat from 10–12m wide, enclosing an island 38m x 43m.
This consists of a water-filled moat which is lined with a stone wall. The house burnt down in the 1660s and a 1840 house now occupies the platform.
A former parish boundary cross which consists of a pillar in buff sandstone with a broken top. It is listed at GradeII.
The remains consist of a mound with an encircling earthwork.
An enclosure surrounded by a rectangular moat measuring 53m x 43m which is now dry; the southern arm has been destroyed.
A dry rectangular moat with associated channels. It is the only Cheshire moat on a hillside and is the highest in the county.
A water-filled moat. The present hall lies to the south.
A rectangular moated site with no sign of a building on the platform. Adjacent is another moat which was probably a fishpond.
A stone marking the boundary between Nether Alderley and Over Alderley.
This consists of a square sandstone block with a hollow in its top. It is sited at a road junction and was probably the base for a cross.
This consists of a motte 4–5m high, and a D-shaped moated enclosure.
The earthworks consist of a mound, the remains of the motte, surrounded by a ditch with the bailey to the southeast.
This consists of two moated platforms with associated field systems.
The holy well consists of a stone wellhead and drainage channel.
Three sides of the moat are preserved as a stone-lined ornamental pond. A 16th-century hall stands on the platform.
A sandstone block which was a waymarker. It is listed at GradeII.

This consists of the remains of a house built in 1380, and subsequently extended, which used to contain a timber-framed hall. It partly collapsed in 1927 and was abandoned leaving a shell of the building which is listed at GradeII*.
Tatton settlement, old hall and mill dam
A quadrilateral enclosure whose purpose is uncertain.
A dry moat to the east of Upton Grange.
The moat was trapezoidal in shape and it enclosed a platform 90m square.

The remains of medieval wayside cross at the junction of four lanes which consist of a square section of a shaft standing on a socket stone on a number of pieces of stone from a later date. It is listed at GradeII*.
A moat surrounding a platform 40msquare with outlet channels, a causeway and a nearby fishpond.
